canonical_explanation.text: The human body has several organ systems that work together. The nervous system controls and coordinates all body activities. It consists of the brain (control centre), spinal cord (connects brain to body), and nerves (carry messages). The circulatory system pumps blood through the body using the heart, arteries, veins, and capillaries. Blood carries oxygen and nutrients to all parts and removes waste. The respiratory system helps us breathe. The lungs take in oxygen from the air and release carbon dioxide. We have five sense organs: eyes (sight), ears (hearing), nose (smell), tongue (taste), and skin (touch). We must take care of our body systems through proper hygiene, exercise, and nutrition.
rules: Brain: control centre of the body
Spinal cord: connects brain to rest of body
Nerves: carry messages to and from brain
Heart: pumps blood throughout the body
Arteries: carry blood away from the heart
Veins: carry blood back to the heart
We breathe in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide
Five sense organs: eyes, ears, nose, tongue, skin
Each sense organ detects a specific type of information

questions.question_text: Which organ is called the control centre of the human body?
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is the control centre of the body. It receives messages from all parts of the body through nerves and sends instructions back to control all body activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart pumps blood, the lungs help in breathing, and the stomach digests food, but none of them controls the entire body. The brain is the control centre because it processes information and coordinates all body functions.

questions.question_text: What is the main function of nerves in our body?

options.text: To carry messages to and from the brain

questions.explanation_correct: Nerves carry messages (signals) to and from the brain. They act like wires connecting the brain to all parts of the body, allowing the brain to receive information and send instructions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pumping blood is the function of the heart, digesting food is done by the digestive system, and breathing is done by the lungs. Nerves specifically carry messages between the brain and different body parts.

questions.question_text: The spinal cord connects the _____ to the rest of the body.
questions.explanation_correct: The spinal cord connects the brain to the rest of the body. It runs inside the backbone and carries messages between the brain and all other parts of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The spinal cord does not connect the heart, lungs, or stomach to the body. It is a long bundle of nerves that runs from the brain down through the backbone, connecting the brain to the rest of the body.

questions.question_text: The nervous system is made up of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The nervous system consists of three main parts: the brain (control centre), the spinal cord (connects brain to body), and the nerves (carry messages throughout the body).
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is actually true. The nervous system is made up of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves. Together, these three parts control and coordinate all the activities of our body.

questions.question_text: Riya accidentally touches a hot pan and quickly pulls her hand away. Which system is mainly responsible for this quick reaction?
questions.explanation_correct: The nervous system is responsible for quick reactions like pulling your hand away from a hot pan. The nerves in the skin sense the heat and quickly send a message to the brain, which then sends a message to the muscles to pull the hand away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The digestive system helps digest food, the circulatory system pumps blood, and the respiratory system helps in breathing. None of these are responsible for quick reactions to danger. The nervous system detects the heat through nerves and coordinates the quick response.

questions.question_text: Aman is solving a difficult maths problem. Which part of his nervous system is working the hardest?
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is working the hardest when solving a maths problem because thinking, reasoning, and problem-solving are all controlled by the brain. It is the centre for all mental activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the spinal cord and nerves are part of the nervous system, they mainly carry messages. The brain is the part that handles thinking, memory, and problem-solving, so it works the hardest when Aman is solving a maths problem.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of the nervous system?

options.text: It breaks down food into nutrients
It pumps blood to all parts of the body
It controls and coordinates all body activities
It removes waste from the body

questions.explanation_correct: The nervous system controls and coordinates all body activities. The brain receives information from sense organs, processes it, and sends instructions to different parts of the body through the spinal cord and nerves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breaking down food is done by the digestive system. Pumping blood is done by the circulatory system. Removing waste is done by the excretory system. The nervous system's specific role is to control and coordinate all activities of the body.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The brain is protected by the skull.
Reason: The brain is a very important and delicate organ.
Choose the correct option.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is true but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. The brain is indeed protected by the skull (assertion is true), and the reason it needs this protection is that it is a very important and delicate organ (reason is true and explains the assertion). The skull acts like a helmet to protect the brain from injury.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true because the skull does protect the brain. The reason is also true because the brain is the most important organ that controls all body functions, and it is soft and delicate. The reason correctly explains why the brain needs the protection of the skull.

questions.question_text: Which organ pumps blood to all parts of the body?
questions.explanation_correct: The heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood to all parts of the body. It beats continuously, sending blood through blood vessels to deliver oxygen and nutrients to every cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lungs help us breathe, the brain controls body activities, and the kidneys filter waste from blood. The heart is the organ that pumps blood throughout the body non-stop.

questions.question_text: Blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Arteries are blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart to different parts of the body. They have thick walls because the blood in arteries flows with high pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins carry blood back to the heart, not away from it. Capillaries are tiny blood vessels that connect arteries to veins. Nerves are part of the nervous system, not the circulatory system. Arteries are the correct answer because they carry blood away from the heart.

questions.question_text: Which blood vessels carry blood back to the heart?
questions.explanation_correct: Veins carry blood back to the heart. After the blood has delivered oxygen and nutrients to body cells, it returns to the heart through veins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arteries carry blood away from the heart, not back to it. Capillaries are tiny vessels connecting arteries and veins. Muscles are not blood vessels. Veins are the correct answer because they bring used blood back to the heart.

questions.question_text: The heart is about the size of your fist.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The human heart is roughly the size of a closed fist. Despite its small size, it is a powerful muscle that pumps blood throughout the body without stopping.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is actually true. The heart is about the size of your fist. It may seem small, but it is very strong and pumps blood to every part of the body continuously.

questions.question_text: After running in the school playground, Priya notices her heart is beating faster. Why does this happen?

options.text: Because her brain has stopped working
Because her body needs more oxygen, so the heart pumps blood faster
Because she ate too much food
Because the weather is too hot

questions.explanation_correct: When we exercise or run, our muscles need more oxygen and energy. The heart beats faster to pump more blood to the muscles, delivering the extra oxygen they need.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart beats faster during exercise because the body needs more oxygen, not because of the other reasons. When muscles work hard during running, they need more oxygen, so the heart pumps blood faster to supply it.

questions.question_text: What would happen if the blood vessels in our body stopped working?

options.text: We would not be able to hear
We would not be able to see
Oxygen and nutrients would not reach body parts
We would not be able to think

questions.explanation_correct: Blood vessels are the pathways through which blood travels. If they stopped working, blood could not carry oxygen and nutrients to different parts of the body, and waste could not be removed. This would be very dangerous for the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While all body functions would eventually be affected, the direct result of blood vessels not working is that oxygen and nutrients cannot reach the body parts. Blood vessels are the transport system of the body.

questions.question_text:
Match the following:
(i) Arteries - (a) Carry blood back to heart
(ii) Veins - (b) Connect arteries to veins
(iii) Capillaries - (c) Carry blood away from heart
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matching is: Arteries carry blood away from the heart (c), Veins carry blood back to the heart (a), and Capillaries are tiny blood vessels that connect arteries to veins (b).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Arteries carry blood Away from the heart (both start with 'A'). Veins carry blood back to the heart. Capillaries are the tiny connections between arteries and veins where exchange of gases and nutrients happens.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the circulatory system is INCORRECT?

options.text: The heart pumps blood to all parts of the body
Arteries carry blood away from the heart
Veins carry blood away from the heart
Blood carries oxygen and nutrients to body cells

questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'Veins carry blood away from the heart' is incorrect. Veins actually carry blood back to the heart, not away from it. Arteries are the blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct statements about the circulatory system. Option C is incorrect because veins carry blood back to the heart, not away from it. It is arteries that carry blood away from the heart.

questions.question_text: Which organs help us breathe?
questions.explanation_correct: The lungs are the main organs of the respiratory system that help us breathe. They take in oxygen from the air we breathe in and release carbon dioxide when we breathe out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kidneys filter waste from blood, the liver processes nutrients, and the stomach digests food. The lungs are the organs responsible for breathing and gas exchange.

questions.question_text: When we breathe in, we take in:
questions.explanation_correct: When we breathe in (inhale), we take in oxygen from the air. Oxygen is essential for our body to produce energy from the food we eat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We breathe in oxygen, not carbon dioxide, nitrogen, or hydrogen. Carbon dioxide is what we breathe out. Oxygen is the gas our body needs to survive and produce energy.

questions.question_text: When we breathe out, we release:
questions.explanation_correct: When we breathe out (exhale), we release carbon dioxide. This is a waste gas produced by our body when it uses oxygen to get energy from food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We breathe out carbon dioxide, not oxygen. Oxygen is what we breathe in. Carbon dioxide is a waste product that our body produces and needs to get rid of through breathing.

questions.question_text: We have two lungs in our chest.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. We have two lungs, one on each side of the chest. They are protected by the rib cage. The left lung is slightly smaller than the right lung to make room for the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Humans have two lungs located in the chest cavity, protected by the ribs. The right lung is slightly larger than the left lung.

questions.question_text: Vikram blows air on a mirror and sees it become foggy. What does the fogginess on the mirror show?

options.text: The air we breathe out contains dust
The air we breathe out contains water vapour
The air we breathe out is very hot

questions.explanation_correct: The fogginess on the mirror shows that the air we breathe out contains water vapour (moisture). When this warm, moist air hits the cooler mirror surface, the water vapour condenses into tiny water droplets, making the mirror foggy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fogginess is not caused by dust, dirt, or heat alone. It is caused by water vapour in our exhaled breath condensing on the cool mirror surface. This is a simple way to show that the air we breathe out contains moisture.

questions.question_text: Why do we breathe faster when we climb stairs quickly?

options.text: Because we feel scared of heights
Because our body needs more oxygen during exercise
Because the air is thinner at higher floors

questions.explanation_correct: When we climb stairs or do any physical activity, our muscles work harder and need more energy. To produce this energy, our body needs more oxygen. So we breathe faster to take in more oxygen to meet the body's increased demand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We breathe faster during exercise because our body needs more oxygen, not because of fear or thinner air. The lungs do not grow bigger. Our muscles need extra oxygen to produce the energy required for physical activities like climbing stairs.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of air flow during breathing in is:
questions.explanation_correct: When we breathe in, air enters through the nose, then passes through the windpipe (trachea), and finally reaches the lungs. This is the correct path: Nose → Windpipe → Lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air does not go directly from the nose to the lungs. It must pass through the windpipe (trachea) first. The correct order is Nose → Windpipe → Lungs. The nose filters and warms the air, the windpipe carries it down, and the lungs absorb the oxygen.

questions.question_text: How many sense organs do we have?
questions.explanation_correct: We have five sense organs: eyes (sight), ears (hearing), nose (smell), tongue (taste), and skin (touch). Each sense organ helps us perceive the world around us in a different way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We have five sense organs, not three, four, or six. The five sense organs are eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin. They help us see, hear, smell, taste, and feel things around us.

questions.question_text: Which sense organ helps us to smell?
questions.explanation_correct: The nose is the sense organ that helps us smell. It can detect thousands of different smells, from the fragrance of flowers to the smell of food cooking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eyes help us see, the tongue helps us taste, and the skin helps us feel touch. The nose is the organ of smell. It helps us detect different odours around us.

questions.question_text: The tongue helps us to:
questions.explanation_correct: The tongue is the sense organ for taste. It can detect different tastes like sweet, sour, salty, and bitter. It also helps us in speaking and swallowing food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tongue is not used for seeing, hearing, or smelling. Eyes help us see, ears help us hear, and the nose helps us smell. The tongue is specifically the organ of taste.

questions.question_text: Which sense organ is the largest in the human body?
questions.explanation_correct: The skin is the largest sense organ in the human body. It covers the entire body and helps us feel touch, pressure, heat, cold, and pain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes, ears, and tongue are all much smaller than the skin. The skin covers the entire body from head to toe, making it the largest organ as well as the largest sense organ.

questions.question_text: Meera is in the kitchen and can tell that her mother is making biryani without looking. Which sense organ helped her know this?
questions.explanation_correct: Meera could tell her mother was making biryani by the smell, which means she used her nose. The nose can detect different aromas and helps us identify food and other things even without seeing them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since Meera was not looking at the food, she did not use her eyes. She identified the food by its smell, using her nose. The nose is the sense organ that detects different aromas and fragrances.

questions.question_text: Arjun is blindfolded during a game. He can still tell that someone is clapping behind him. Which sense organ is he using?
questions.explanation_correct: Arjun is using his ears to hear the clapping sound. Even though he is blindfolded and cannot see, his ears can detect the sound of clapping and tell him what is happening around him.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arjun cannot use his eyes because he is blindfolded. He cannot use his nose or tongue to detect clapping. He is using his ears, which are the sense organs for hearing, to identify the clapping sound.

questions.question_text: Kavya picks up an ice cube and feels that it is very cold. Which sense organ helped her feel this?
questions.explanation_correct: The skin is the sense organ that helps us feel temperature (hot or cold), pressure, and texture. When Kavya picks up the ice cube, the skin on her hand senses the cold temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eyes help see, nose helps smell, and tongue helps taste. The skin is the sense organ responsible for feeling touch, temperature, and pressure. Kavya felt the coldness of the ice cube through her skin.

questions.question_text:
Match the sense organs with their functions:
(i) Eyes - (a) Hearing
(ii) Ears - (b) Taste
(iii) Tongue - (c) Sight
(iv) Nose - (d) Smell
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matching is: Eyes - Sight (c), Ears - Hearing (a), Tongue - Taste (b), Nose - Smell (d). Each sense organ has a specific function that helps us perceive the world.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Eyes are for seeing (sight), Ears are for hearing, Tongue is for tasting, and Nose is for smelling. The correct match is (i)-c, (ii)-a, (iii)-b, (iv)-d.

questions.question_text: A person who cannot see is called blind. Which sense organs do blind people rely on more to understand their surroundings?
questions.explanation_correct: Blind people rely more on their ears (hearing) and skin (touch) to understand their surroundings. They listen to sounds to know what is happening and use touch to read Braille and identify objects. They also use their nose (smell) but ears and touch are the most important.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blind people do not rely on just one sense organ. They use multiple senses, especially hearing (ears) and touch (skin), to navigate and understand the world. They listen to sounds and feel objects with their hands to compensate for the loss of sight.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a good habit for taking care of our eyes?

options.text: Reading in proper light and taking breaks from screens

questions.explanation_correct: Reading in proper light and taking regular breaks from screens is a good habit for eye care. It reduces strain on the eyes and helps keep them healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reading in dim light, looking at the sun, and rubbing eyes with dirty hands are all harmful to the eyes. The correct way to take care of eyes is to read in proper light, take breaks from screens, and wash hands before touching the eyes.

questions.question_text: To take care of our ears, we should NOT:

options.text: Insert sharp objects into the ear
Visit a doctor if we have ear pain
Protect our ears from very loud sounds

questions.explanation_correct: We should never insert sharp objects like pins, pencils, or sticks into our ears. This can damage the eardrum and cause hearing loss. If ears need cleaning, it should be done carefully or by a doctor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Keeping ears clean, visiting a doctor for ear problems, and protecting ears from loud sounds are all good habits. Inserting sharp objects into the ear is the only harmful action listed, as it can damage the delicate parts inside the ear.

questions.question_text: Rohan listens to very loud music through earphones for many hours every day. What problem could this cause?
questions.explanation_correct: Listening to very loud music through earphones for long hours can damage the delicate parts inside the ear and lead to hearing loss. We should always keep the volume at a safe level and take breaks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loud music through earphones directly affects the ears, not the eyes, skin, or stomach. The sound waves can damage the eardrum and other delicate parts of the ear, leading to hearing problems over time.

questions.question_text: Sita's grandmother told her to eat carrots for better eyesight. Which nutrient in carrots helps the eyes?
questions.explanation_correct: Carrots are rich in Vitamin A, which is very important for good eyesight. Lack of Vitamin A can cause night blindness. Other foods rich in Vitamin A include papaya, mango, and green leafy vegetables.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While all vitamins are important, it is Vitamin A specifically that helps maintain good eyesight. Carrots are rich in Vitamin A. Vitamin C helps in healing wounds, Vitamin D helps bones, and calcium makes bones and teeth strong.

questions.question_text: The brain, spinal cord, and nerves together make up the _____ system.
questions.explanation_correct: The brain, spinal cord, and nerves together make up the nervous system. This system controls and coordinates all the activities of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The digestive system breaks down food, the circulatory system transports blood, and the respiratory system helps in breathing. The brain, spinal cord, and nerves together form the nervous system.

questions.question_text: The _____ pumps blood to all parts of the body.
questions.explanation_correct: The heart pumps blood to all parts of the body. It is a muscular organ that beats non-stop to keep blood flowing through arteries, veins, and capillaries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain controls the body, lungs help in breathing, and kidneys filter waste. It is the heart that pumps blood to all parts of the body through blood vessels.

questions.question_text: We breathe in _____ and breathe out _____.
questions.explanation_correct: We breathe in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide. Our body uses oxygen to get energy from food, and carbon dioxide is produced as a waste gas that we exhale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is oxygen (breathe in) and carbon dioxide (breathe out). Our body needs oxygen to produce energy, and carbon dioxide is the waste gas that must be removed from the body.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the circulatory system?
questions.explanation_correct: The windpipe (trachea) is part of the respiratory system, not the circulatory system. It carries air to and from the lungs. The circulatory system consists of the heart, arteries, veins, capillaries, and blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart, arteries, and veins are all parts of the circulatory system. The windpipe belongs to the respiratory system and is used for carrying air during breathing, not blood.

questions.question_text: Why is it better to breathe through the nose rather than the mouth?

options.text: The nose is bigger than the mouth
The nose filters, warms, and moistens the air before it reaches the lungs
The mouth is only for eating
Breathing through the nose is faster

questions.explanation_correct: Breathing through the nose is better because the nose has tiny hairs and mucus that filter dust and germs from the air. It also warms and moistens the air before it reaches the lungs, protecting them from harm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main reason is that the nose acts as a filter for the air. The tiny hairs and mucus in the nose trap dust particles and germs, and the nose warms and moistens the air. This makes the air cleaner and safer for the lungs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of sense organ and sense is CORRECT?
questions.explanation_correct: Skin - Touch is the correct pair. The skin is the sense organ for the sense of touch. It helps us feel pressure, temperature, pain, and texture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ears are for hearing (not smell), Nose is for smell (not hearing), and Tongue is for taste (not touch). The only correct pairing in the options is Skin - Touch.

questions.question_text: Plants also take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide, just like humans.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Plants also respire (breathe) and during respiration they take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide, just like animals and humans. This happens all the time, day and night. However, during the day, plants also perform photosynthesis, which uses carbon dioxide and releases oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is actually true. While plants are known for producing oxygen during photosynthesis, they also respire like animals. During respiration, plants take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way to keep the respiratory system healthy?

options.text: Exercising regularly and breathing fresh air

questions.explanation_correct: Exercising regularly and breathing fresh air keeps the respiratory system healthy. Exercise makes the lungs stronger and helps them work better. Fresh air ensures that clean oxygen reaches the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polluted air damages the lungs, smoking is very harmful to the respiratory system, and staying indoors all day does not give the lungs enough exercise. Regular exercise and fresh air are the best ways to keep the respiratory system healthy.

questions.question_text: Neha's baby brother cannot walk or talk yet, but he can blink his eyes when something comes close to his face. Which part of the nervous system helps him do this automatically?
questions.explanation_correct: The brain controls automatic responses like blinking. When something comes close to the baby's face, the eyes send a signal to the brain, and the brain quickly sends a signal back to close the eyelids. This is called a reflex action and it protects the eyes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart, stomach, and lungs do not control blinking. It is the brain that processes the signal from the eyes and commands the eyelids to close automatically. This quick automatic response is called a reflex.

questions.question_text: A doctor uses a stethoscope to check a patient. What does the stethoscope help the doctor hear?

options.text: The sounds of the brain thinking
The sound of blood in the nerves

questions.explanation_correct: A stethoscope helps the doctor hear the heartbeat. The heart makes a 'lub-dub' sound each time it beats and pumps blood. The doctor listens to this sound to check if the heart is healthy and working properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain does not make sounds that can be heard, and nerves do not produce sounds. A stethoscope is designed to hear the heartbeat and sometimes breathing sounds. The 'lub-dub' sound of the heart tells the doctor about its health.

questions.question_text: Capillaries are the thinnest blood vessels that connect arteries to veins.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Capillaries are the thinnest blood vessels in the body. They connect arteries to veins and are so thin that blood cells pass through them in a single line. It is through the capillary walls that exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste takes place.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Capillaries are indeed the thinnest blood vessels. They form a network connecting arteries to veins and allow the exchange of gases and nutrients between blood and body cells.

questions.question_text: Rahul has a bad cold and his nose is blocked. He finds it difficult to enjoy the taste of his favourite rajma chawal. Why?

options.text: Because his tongue has stopped working
Because the sense of smell and taste work together, and a blocked nose reduces taste
Because rajma chawal does not taste good when it is cold
Because the cold makes all food bitter

questions.explanation_correct: The senses of smell and taste are closely connected. When the nose is blocked due to a cold, we cannot smell the food properly, which reduces our ability to enjoy its full taste. That is why food seems tasteless when we have a cold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rahul's tongue is still working, but the full experience of taste depends on both the tongue and the nose working together. When the nose is blocked, we lose much of the flavour experience because smell and taste are closely linked.

questions.question_text: The _____ is the sense organ for touch and is the largest organ of the body.
questions.explanation_correct: The skin is the sense organ for touch and is the largest organ of the human body. It covers the entire body and helps us feel temperature, pressure, pain, and texture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tongue is for taste, the nose is for smell, and the ear is for hearing. The skin is both the organ of touch and the largest organ of the body, covering our entire body surface.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions helps protect ALL body systems?

options.text: Eating a balanced diet, exercising, and getting enough sleep

questions.explanation_correct: Eating a balanced diet provides all the nutrients our body needs, exercise keeps our organs strong and healthy, and adequate sleep allows the body to rest and repair. Together, these three habits protect all body systems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating only sweets does not provide all nutrients. Too little sleep weakens the body. Watching TV all day means no exercise. The best way to protect all body systems is through a balanced diet, regular exercise, and enough sleep.
